Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: Mobilizing New England Vascular Plant Specimen Data to Track Environmental Changes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Herbarium specimens provide a source of historical information useful to the study of global environmental change. The goal of this project is to provide data to support studies of the nature and consequences of environmental change in the New England region over the last three centuries. This project will digitally capture specimen data and images from about 1.3 million vascular plant specimens from herbaria across New England, enhancing the data with georeferencing, habitat, and phonological information. The digitization process will integrate with existing community efforts and will develop novel high-throughput digitization technologies to increase efficiency and decrease costs. All resulting data and images will be freely available on-line.

The data from this project will be of immediate use to scientists who study climate and land-use change, and will provide a better understanding of how global changes will impact the distribution of native and introduced plant species. This project will benefit research in taxonomy, ecology, morphology, biogeography, and evolutionary history by making available data on an entire regional flora in an electronic format. The methodologies developed will provide a model for other regions around the nation. In addition the project will utilize citizen scientists, school groups, and students providing training, research, and educational opportunities. . This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

Institution.Name: University of Vermont & State Agricultural College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & STATE AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pringle Herbarium, part of the Natural History Museum at the University of Vermont (UVM), was throughout its activity a partner in the Thematic Collections Network (TCN) called “Collaborative Research: Digitization TCN: Mobilizing New England Vascular Plant Specimen Data to Track Environmental Changes” The central goals for the TCN was to create a data set catered to the study of climate change and land use history in New England. During the project’s funded history, institutions digitized almost 1.3 million New England vascular plant specimens from 15 small to large herbaria located across the region. We enhanced the images and herbarium label data that we collected by generating geographic coordinates and phenological and habitat data using controlled vocabularies developed as part of the project. The digitization process was integrated into existing community efforts, largely utilizing community developed software. We integrated the resulting data into existing regional, national, and global databases. This project yielded a network of citizen scientists and school groups positioned to gather current phenological data that can be compared with herbarium data that will be gathered from digitized specimens.   

This Pringle Herbarium’s own role as a collaborating institution in the Mobilizing New England Vascular Plant Specimen Data to Track Environmental Changes (NEVP) project has been to capture specimen data and images from 79,000 vascular plant specimens (up from the original estimate of 65,000) housed in the herbarium and then share the resulting images and data online. The digitization process at the Pringle Herbarium has been integrated with those of the other institutions as part of overall activity.  All resulting data and images are freely available online. The Pringle Herbarium's plan, like the overall digitization plan for the NEVP TCN project, had three main components: 1) Precapture (preliminary assessment of the  physical storage structure of the New England collections in the general herbarium); 2) Primary Digitization (an image, a barcode number, and a subset of label data will be captured and precapture data will be associated with specimen occurrence records); 3) Secondary Digitization ( capture of habitat and phenology data from images of specimens and labels and georeferencing to the town level). 

Early in the funding period for this grant, the Pringle Herbarium won the dedicated use of additional space in its building, Torrey Hall, where a permanent Digitization Center was established including two complete work stations, each with image-capture devices and associated computers. The Pringle Herbarium staff and students captured specimen-level data (species name, collection code, catalog number, state name) and an image for a total of 77,000 specimens (All New England specimens in the Pringle Herbarium) at a cost of ca. $0.45 per specimen without overhead. Virtually all of these specimens are available on the portal (neherbaria.org/portal). Secondary digitization during the life of this grant was completed for about 37,000 specimens.

The work at the Pringle Herbarium over the course of the NSF NEVP ADBC Grant has resulted in training of 25 undergraduates and recent graduates in digitization and in plant biodiversity informatics, including plant classification and herbarium organization and curation. Training of four MS and PhD students in systematics relating to the implementation and use of herbarium-based data was also a constant characteristic of the activities at the herbarium.  Training in coding and web application development was provided for one undergraduate funded with a federal work-study grant. The grant also provided substantial professional development for Dr. Dorothy Allard, the primary supervisor and mentor to undergraduate workers. Dr. Allard, as well as three recent graduates, were funded as staff members of the Pringle Virtual Herbarium over the life of the project. 

At the close of this project, the Pringle Herbarium's holdings of New England vascular plants are completely digitized and available to the community at large on line.  The activities funded by this grant brought the collection into a new era, one in which the goal of realizing full digitization of the entire world collection at the Pringle became possible.

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2017
Modified by: David S Barrington

During the project?s funded history, institutions digitized almost 1.3 million New England vascular plant specimens from 15 small to large herbaria located across the region. We enhanced the images and herbarium label data that we collected by generating geographic coordinates and phenological and habitat data using controlled vocabularies developed as part of the project. We integrated the resulting data into existing regional, national, and global databases. This project yielded a network of citizen scientists and school groups positioned to gather current phenological data that can be compared with herbarium data that will be gathered from digitized specimens. Early in the funding period for this grant, the Pringle Herbarium won the dedicated use of additional space in its building, Torrey Hall, where a permanent Digitization Center was established including two complete work stations, each with image-capture devices and associated computers. The Pringle Herbarium staff and students captured specimen-level data (species name, collection code, catalog number, state name) and an image for a total of 77,000 specimens (All New England specimens in the Pringle Herbarium) at a cost of ca. $0.45 per specimen without overhead. Virtually all of these specimens are available on the portal (neherbaria.org/portal). Secondary digitization during the life of this grant was completed for about 37,000 specimens. Dr. Allard, as well as three recent graduates, were funded as staff members of the Pringle Virtual Herbarium over the life of the project. The activities funded by this grant brought the collection into a new era, one in which the goal of realizing full digitization of the entire world collection at the Pringle became possible.
